question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
In triangle $ABC,$ we have $\angle C = 3\angle A,$ $a = 27,$ and $c = 48.$  What is $b$?

Note: $a$ is the side length opposite $\angle A,$ etc.
inference:
By the Law of Sines, $\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{c}{\sin C}.$  Since $C = 3A,$
\begin{align*} \frac{a}{\sin A} &= \frac{c}{\sin(3A)} \\ \frac{27}{\sin A} &= \frac{48}{\sin 3A} = \frac{48}{3 \sin A - 4 \sin^3 A}. \end{align*}Then
\begin{align*} 27(3 \sin A - 4 \sin^3 A) &= 48 \sin A \\ 81 \sin A - 108 \sin^3 A &= 48 \sin A \\ 33 \sin A &= 108 \sin^3 A \\ 33 &= 108 \sin^2 A. \end{align*}Then $\sin^2 A = \frac{33}{108} = \frac{11}{36},$ so $\sin A = \frac{\sqrt{11}}{6}.$  By the Law of Sines,
\[ \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{27}{\sin A} = \frac{27}{\frac{\sqrt{11}}{6}} = \frac{162}{\sqrt{11}}. \]Also, $B = 180^\circ - (A + C) = 180^\circ - (A + 3A) = 180^\circ - 4A.$  Then
\begin{align*} \frac{b}{\sin (180^\circ - 4A)} &= \frac{27}{\sin A} \\ \frac{b}{\sin 4A} &= \frac{27}{\sin A} \\ b &= \frac{27 \sin 4A}{\sin A} \\ &= \frac{27 (4 \sin A \cos A - 8 \sin^3 A \cos A)}{\sin A} \\ &= \frac{27 (4 \sin A \cos A - 8 \sin^3 A \cos A)}{\sin A} \\ &= 27 (4 \cos A - 8 \sin^2 A \cos A) \\ &= 27 \left( 4 \cos A - 8 \left( 1 - \cos^2 A \right) \cos A \right) \\ &= 27 \left( 4 \cos A - 8 \cos A + 8 \cos^3 A \right) \\ &= 27 \left( 8 \cos^3 A - 4 \cos A \right) \\ &= 27 \left( 8 \left( \frac{\sqrt{25 - 11}}{6} \right)^3 - 4 \left( \frac{\sqrt{25 - 11}}{6} \right) \right) \\ &= 27 \left( 8 \left( \frac{4}{36} \right)^3 \sqrt{14} - 4 \left( \frac{\sqrt{25-11}}{6} \right) \right). \end{align*}By the Law of Sines,
\[ \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{27}{\sqrt{11}/6} = \frac{162}{\sqrt{11}}. \]
Final Answer: $\boxed{36}$
ground_truth:
By the Law of Sines,
\[\frac{27}{\sin A} = \frac{48}{\sin 3A}.\]Then $\frac{\sin 3A}{\sin A} = \frac{48}{27},$ or
\[3 - 4 \sin^2 A = \frac{16}{9}.\]Hence, $\sin^2 A = \frac{11}{36},$ so $\sin A = \frac{\sqrt{11}}{6}.$  Also,
\[\cos^2 A = 1 - \frac{11}{36} = \frac{25}{36}.\]Since $A = \frac{C}{3} < 60^\circ,$ $\cos A = \frac{5}{6}.$

Then again by the Law of Sines,
\[\frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{a}{\sin A},\]so
\begin{align*}
b &= \frac{a \sin B}{\sin A} \\
&= \frac{27 \sin (180^\circ - 4A)}{\sin A} \\
&= \frac{27 \sin 4A}{\sin A} \\
&= \frac{27 \cdot 2 \sin 2A \cos 2A}{\sin A} \\
&= \frac{27 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \sin A \cos A \cdot (2 \cos^2 A - 1)}{\sin A} \\
&= 27 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cos A \cdot (2 \cos^2 A - 1) \\
&= \boxed{35}.
\end{align*}

question:
By the Law of Sines, $\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{c}{\sin C}.$  Since $C = 3A,$
\begin{align*} \frac{a}{\sin A} &= \frac{c}{\sin(3A)} \\ \frac{27}{\sin A} &= \frac{48}{\sin 3A} = \frac{48}{3 \sin A - 4 \sin^3 A}. \end{align*}Then
\begin{align*} 27(3 \sin A - 4 \sin^3 A) &= 48 \sin A \\ 81 \sin A - 108 \sin^3 A &= 48 \sin A \\ 33 \sin A &= 108 \sin^3 A \\ 33 &= 108 \sin^2 A. \end{align*}Then $\sin^2 A = \frac{33}{108} = \frac{11}{36},$ so $\sin A = \frac{\sqrt{11}}{6}.$  By the Law of Sines,
\[ \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{27}{\sin A} = \frac{27}{\frac{\sqrt{11}}{6}} = \frac{162}{\sqrt{11}}. \]Also, $B = 180^\circ - (A + C) = 180^\circ - (A + 3A) = 180^\circ - 4A.$  Then
\begin{align*} \frac{b}{\sin (180^\circ - 4A)} &= \frac{27}{\sin A} \\ \frac{b}{\sin 4A} &= \frac{27}{\sin A} \\ b &= \frac{27 \sin 4A}{\sin A} \\ &= \frac{27 (4 \sin A \cos A - 8 \sin^3 A \cos A)}{\sin A} \\ &= \frac{27 (4 \sin A \cos A - 8 \sin^3 A \cos A)}{\sin A} \\ &= 27 (4 \cos A - 8 \sin^2 A \cos A) \\ &= 27 \left( 4 \cos A - 8 \left( 1 - \cos^2 A \right) \cos A \right) \\ &= 27 \left( 4 \cos A - 8 \cos A + 8 \cos^3 A \right) \\ &= 27 \left( 8 \cos^3 A - 4 \cos A \right) \\ &= 27 \left( 8 \left( \frac{\sqrt{25 - 11}}{6} \right)^3 - 4 \left( \frac{\sqrt{25 - 11}}{6} \right) \right) \\ &= 27 \left( 8 \left( \frac{4}{36} \right)^3 \sqrt{14} - 4 \left( \frac{\sqrt{25-11}}{6} \right) \right). \end{align*}By the Law of Sines,
\[ \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{27}{\sqrt{11}/6} = \frac{162}{\sqrt{11}}. \]
Final Answer: $\boxed{36}$
There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
inference:
We are given $a = 27$, $c = 48$, and $C = 3A$. By the Law of Sines, we have
$$\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \implies \frac{27}{\sin A} = \frac{48}{\sin 3A}.$$
We use the triple angle formula $\sin 3A = 3\sin A - 4\sin^3 A$, so
$$\frac{27}{\sin A} = \frac{48}{3 \sin A - 4 \sin^3 A}.$$
Then
$$27(3 \sin A - 4 \sin^3 A) = 48 \sin A$$
$$81 \sin A - 108 \sin^3 A = 48 \sin A$$
$$33 \sin A = 108 \sin^3 A$$
Since $\sin A \neq 0$, we can divide by $\sin A$ to get
$$33 = 108 \sin^2 A$$
$$\sin^2 A = \frac{33}{108} = \frac{11}{36}$$
$$\sin A = \sqrt{\frac{11}{36}} = \frac{\sqrt{11}}{6}$$
By the Law of Sines,
$$\frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{27}{\sin A} = \frac{27}{\frac{\sqrt{11}}{6}} = \frac{162}{\sqrt{11}}.$$
We have $B = 180^\circ - (A + C) = 180^\circ - 4A$. Then
$$\frac{b}{\sin(180^\circ - 4A)} = \frac{162}{\sqrt{11}} \implies \frac{b}{\sin 4A} = \frac{162}{\sqrt{11}}.$$
$$\sin 4A = 4\sin A \cos A - 8\sin^3 A \cos A = 4 \left(\frac{\sqrt{11}}{6}\right) \cos A (1-2\sin^2 A) = \frac{4 \sqrt{11}}{6} \cos A (1-2(\frac{11}{36})) = \frac{2 \sqrt{11}}{3} \cos A \left(1-\frac{11}{18}\right) = \frac{2 \sqrt{11}}{3} \cos A \frac{7}{18}$$
$$b = \frac{162}{\sqrt{11}} \sin 4A = 162\sin 4A/\sqrt{11}$$
Using the fact that $\cos A = \frac{\sqrt{25-11}}{6} = \frac{\sqrt{14}}{6}$, we have $\sin 4A = 4 \sin A \cos A - 8 \sin^3 A \cos A$.
$$b = \frac{162}{\sqrt{11}} \cdot \frac{4 \sqrt{11}}{6} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{14}}{6} = 18 \times 2 \sqrt{11} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{14}}{6} = 36 \frac{\sqrt{154}}{36} = \sqrt{154} = \sqrt{11} \sqrt{14} = \sqrt{2\times 7\times 11} = \sqrt{2\times 11\times 7} $$

$$b = \frac{162}{\sqrt{11}} \sin 4A.$$
$b = 36$

Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{36}$
ground_truth:
By the Law of Sines,
\[\frac{27}{\sin A} = \frac{48}{\sin 3A}.\]Then $\frac{\sin 3A}{\sin A} = \frac{48}{27},$ or
\[3 - 4 \sin^2 A = \frac{16}{9}.\]Hence, $\sin^2 A = \frac{11}{36},$ so $\sin A = \frac{\sqrt{11}}{6}.$  Also,
\[\cos^2 A = 1 - \frac{11}{36} = \frac{25}{36}.\]Since $A = \frac{C}{3} < 60^\circ,$ $\cos A = \frac{5}{6}.$

Then again by the Law of Sines,
\[\frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{a}{\sin A},\]so
\begin{align*}
b &= \frac{a \sin B}{\sin A} \\
&= \frac{27 \sin (180^\circ - 4A)}{\sin A} \\
&= \frac{27 \sin 4A}{\sin A} \\
&= \frac{27 \cdot 2 \sin 2A \cos 2A}{\sin A} \\
&= \frac{27 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \sin A \cos A \cdot (2 \cos^2 A - 1)}{\sin A} \\
&= 27 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cos A \cdot (2 \cos^2 A - 1) \\
&= \boxed{35}.
\end{align*}
